PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT WILL MAINTAIN THE ESTABLISHED SARS-COV-2 SURVEILLANCE NORTH AMERICAN CERVID POPULATIONS STARTED BY APHIS WS. THIS PROJECT WILL MAINTAIN THE CURRENT TRAJECTORY AND CONTINUES VITAL RESEARCH AIMED AT BETTER UNDERSTANDING HOW THE SCV-2 VIRUS BEHAVES IN VARIOUS ANIMALS, HOW IT MOVES BETWEEN HUMANS AND ANIMALS, AND WHAT WE AND OUR PUBLIC HEALTH PARTNERS CAN DO TO INTERRUPT THE CHAINS OF TRANSMISSION. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: 1) COORDINATE SAMPLE COLLECTION AND SHIPPING TO APHIS; 2) CONDUCT OUTREACH TO WAFWA MEMBER STATES; 3) CONDUCT OUTREACH TO ALL ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES (AFWA) AND SUBGROUP MEMBER STATES; 4) PROCURE, DISTRIBUTE, AND COORDINATE SAMPLING SUPPLIES TO PARTICIPANTS; 5) COLLABORATE ON ANY MANUSCRIPTS RESULTING FROM THIS COLLABORATION AND RETAIN AUTHORSHIP(S) ON ALL PUBLISHED MANUSCRIPTS; 6) REVIEW ALL REPORTS RESULTING FROM THE COLLABORATION WITHIN 30 DAYS OF RECEIPT. ALL DIAGNOSTIC RESULTS WILL BE SENT TO APHIS. THESE RESULTS WILL BE SHARED WITH PARTICIPATING AGENCIES WHEN THEY BECOME AVAILABLE. THIS IS A POPULATION LEVEL SARS-COV-2 SURVEILLANCE EFFORT TARGETING WHITE-TAILED DEER, MULE DEER AND OTHER CERVIDS. RESULTS FROM STATEWIDE SAMPLING WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE COOPERATING STATE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AGENCY AS THE DATA BECOMES AVAILABLE. WS ENCOURAGES THE COOPERATOR TO WORK JOINTLY WITH APHIS LEGISLATIVE AND PUBLIC AFFAIRS TO PUBLISH OR OTHERWISE MAKE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE THE RESULTS OF THE WORK PERFORMED UNDER THIS AGREEMENT. TEST RESULTS FOR INDIVIDUAL DEER WILL NOT BE MADE PUBLIC. POSITIVE RESULTS WILL BE SHARED WITH THE STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES PRIOR TO SHARING WITH OTHER STAKEHOLDERS AND THE PUBLIC. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE COOPERATOR WILL WORK TOGETHER WITH THE APHIS PROGRAM MANAGER TO COORDINATE COLLECTION OF SARS-COV-2 SAMPLES FROM NORTH AMERICAN CERVID SPECIES BY PARTNERING WITH STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES. TO DATE, THE FIRST YEAR OF WHITE-TAILED DEER SURVEILLANCE, 3 APHIS-LED MANUSCRIPTS ARE CURRENTLY INTHE PEER-REVIEW PROCESS, AND APHIS IS CO-AUTHOR ON AN ADDITIONAL MANUSCRIPT CURRENTLY IN REVIEW. AT LEAST ONE PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATION IS LIKELY TO BE PRODUCED FROM THIS WORK. PRINCIPAL AUTHORSHIP WILL BE RETAINED BY THE COOPERATOR AND CO-AUTHORSHIP WILL BE OFFERED TO THE ASSOCIATED APHIS COLLABORATORS.  THE COOPERATOR WILL COORDINATE WITH APHIS TO ENSURE THAT THE TARGET NUMBERS OF SAMPLES FROM HUNTER-HARVEST WHITE-TAILED DEER, MULE DEER AND OTHER CERVIDS ARE COLLECTED TO MEET THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: ALL FUNDS WILL BE USED TO FURTHER INVESTIGATE SARS-COV-2 IN WILD NORTH AMERICAN CERVID SPECIES. THIS PARTNERSHIP WITH WAFWA FOR CONTINUED SURVEILLANCE OF SARS-COV-2 IN CERVIDS WILL BENEFIT WILDLIFE MANAGERS AND RESEARCHERS, THE HEALTH OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS, AND POTENTIALLY, HUMAN HEALTH AND SAFETY ACROSS THE UNITED STATES. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT INTENDS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO WAFWA MEMBER STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES AS WELL AS MEMBERS OF THE OTHER AFWA SUBGROUPS (MAFWA, SEAFWA, NEAFWA).  WAFWA WILL SUBAWARD FUNDS TO PARTICIPANTS TO COLLECT SARS-COV-2 SAMPLES FROM WHITE-TAILED DEER, MULE DEER, AND OTHER CERVIDS FROM HUNTER-HARVESTED ANIMALS, AND ANIMALS HANDLED VIA OTHER MANAGEMENT ACTIONS.

PURPOSE:  BOBCATS (LYNX RUFUS) FREQUENTLY INHABIT AND TRAVERSE HABITAT AT THE WILDLAND URBAN INTERFACE (WUI), BRINGING THEM INTO CLOSE CONTACT WITH DOMESTIC ANIMALS AND HUMANS. IN ARIZONA, BOBCATS ARE SYMPATRIC WITH OTHER CLOSELY RELATED HOST SPECIES, SUCH AS PUMAS (PUMA CONCOLOR) AND DOMESTIC CATS (FELIS CATUS), CREATING THE POTENTIAL FOR BOBCATS TO SERVE AS LINKS IN DISEASE TRANSMISSION BETWEEN HUMANS, DOMESTIC ANIMALS, AND WILDLIFE SPECIES AT THE WUI. THIS MAY PUT BOBCATS AND OTHER WILDLIFE AT INCREASED RISK OF INFECTION BY PATHOGENS TYPICALLY ASSOCIATED WITH DOMESTIC ANIMALS (ESPECIALLY DOMESTIC CATS) AND EVEN HUMANS (FOR EXAMPLE, SARS-COV-2), AS WELL AS EXPOSE HUMANS TO PATHOGENS WITH ZOONOTIC POTENTIAL. THEREFORE, SURVEYING PATHOGENS IN WIDESPREAD, GENERALIST CARNIVORES SUCH AS BOBCATS CAN ELUCIDATE DISEASE THREATS AT THE NEXUS OF ANIMAL, HUMAN, AND ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH (ONE HEALTH). ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: WE AIM TO EMPLOY A TARGETED VIROME SEQUENCING APPROACH TO SURVEY BOTH KNOWN AND NOVEL VIRUSES IN A POPUL ATION OF URBAN BOBCATS ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF TUCSON, ARIZONA, IN COLLABORATION WITH THE BOBCATS IN TUCSON PROJECT. USING PAIRED HOST AND VIRAL GENOMIC DATA, WE WILL ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES: 1) CHARACTERIZE FECAL AND ORAL VIROME COMPOSITION, INCLUDING IDENTIFICATION OF KNOWN AND NOVEL VIRAL DISEASE THREATS TO BOBCATS AND OTHER WILDLIFE, HUMANS, AND DOMESTIC ANIMALS; ASSESS CONCORDANCE OF VIROME COMPOSITION OF BOTH SAMPLE TYPES USING TWIST BIOSCIENCE’S COMPREHENSIVE VIRAL RESEARCH PANEL. 2) VALIDATE ABILITY OF TWIST BIOSCIENCE’S COMPREHENSIVE VIRAL RESEARCH PANEL TO DETECT SARS-COV-2 THROUGH COMPARING RESULTS WITH RTPCR-BASED DETECTIONS FROM THE SAME FECAL AND BUCCAL SWAB SAMPLES (POSITIVE CONTROLS) 3) IDENTIFY KEY DRIVERS OF FECAL/ORAL VIROME DIVERSITY, INCLUDING DETERMINING THE ROLES OF SPATIAL PROXIMITY AND HOST GENETIC FACTORS (SUCH AS GENETIC DIVERSITY, RELATEDNESS, AND GENE FLOW) IN SHAPING VIROME COMPOSITION. . EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EMPLOY A TARGETED VIROME SEQUENCING APPROACH TO SURVEY BOTH KNOWN AND NOVEL VIRUSES IN A POPULATION OF URBAN BOBCATS ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF TUCSON, ARIZONA. THROUGH THIS APPROACH, WE AIM TO DETECT PATHOGENS RELEVANT TO THE HEALTH OF BOBCATS AND OTHER WILDLIFE, DOMESTIC ANIMALS, AND HUMANS, AS WELL AS GAIN INSIGHT INTO THE TRANSMISSION OF VIRUSES TO AND WITHIN THIS POPULATION AT THE WUI. WE SPECIFICALLY AIM TO VALIDATE THE UTILITY OF THIS APPROACH FOR DETECTING SARS-COV-2 IN BOBCAT SCAT AND BUCCAL SWABS, SINCE THIS VIRUS POSES HEALTH THREATS TO HUMANS AND FELIDS ALIKE. WE ALSO SEEK TO IDENTIFY FACTORS THAT INFLUENCE VIROME COMPOSITION THROUGH INTEGRATING ADDITIONAL DATASETS (I.E., LOCATION AND HOST GENOMIC DATA). THIS IS THE FIRST PROJECT TO PERFORM BROAD VIRUS SURVEILLANCE/MONITORING OF A WILD BOBCAT POPULATIONS THAT WE ARE AWARE OF. OUR MONITORING WILL COVER ONLY A TWO TO THREE YEAR PERIOD OF TIME, AND WHILE WE DO NOT HAVE PLANS FOR FUTURE VIRAL SURVEILLANCE OF BOBCATS IN THE TUCSON AREA, BASED ON OUR RESULTS WE HOPE TO BE ABLE TO ASSIST IN FUTURE PUBLIC HEALTH AND ONEHEALTH PLANNING.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THIS PROJECT HAS IMPLICATIONS TO ONEHEALTH DUE TO THE BOBCAT BEING A SPECIES THAT LIVES IN PROXIMITY TO HUMANS AND OUR DOMESTIC ANIMALS, BUT ALSO THIS VIRUS MONITORING WILL BE A VALUABLE ASSESSMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH VARIABLES WHICH IS LARGELY MISSING IN ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING TO DATE.  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

PURPOSE: TO COLLABORATE ON SARS-COV-2 DATA AND DIAGNOSTIC RESULTS FOR WILD WHITE-TAILED DEER AND POTENTIALLY OTHER WILDLIFE SPECIES FOR COMPUTATIONAL ANALYSES TO DETERMINE THE NATURAL HISTORY AND EVOLUTIONARY DYNAMICS OF SARS-COV-2 DETECTIONS IN WILDLIFE.

PURPOSE: THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVES OF THE COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH EFFORT BETWEEN APHIS, WS AND THE COOPERATOR ARE TO 1) DETERMINE THE PREDICTIVE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN (A) HUMAN VALUES, ATTITUDES, AND BELIEFS AND (B) HUMAN BEHAVIORS AT THE HUMAN-WTD INTERFACE; 2) IDENTIFY HUMAN BEHAVIORS AND LAND-USE CHARACTERISTICS THAT MAY LEAD TO SPILLOVER OR SPILLBACK OF SCV2 FROM HUMANS TO WTD; 3) DETERMINE THE LIKELY RESPONSE OF INDIVIDUALS TO DIFFERENT MANAGEMENT INTERVENTIONS (E.G., PROVISION OF INFORMATION ABOUT RISK AND PREVENTION); AND 4) IMPROVE RISK ASSESSMENT AND FORECASTING CAPABILITIES OF SCV2 HOTSPOTS IN WTD. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE COLLABORATIVE EFFORT WILL INVOLVE CONDUCTING WORKSHOPS AND ADMINISTERING A NATIONWIDE SURVEY TO UNDERSTAND HUMAN-WTD INTERACTIONS AND THE MECHANISMS THAT LEAD TO SCV2 SPILLOVER INTO WTD POPULATIONS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE FINDINGS FROM THIS RESEARCH WILL MAXIMIZE OUR ABILITY TO PREDICT SCV2 SPILLOVER AND SPILLBACK AND TO DESIGN MORE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENTINTERVENTIONS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE AMERICAN PUBLIC, ANIMALS, AND THE ENVIRONMENT. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS APPROACH WILL IDENTIFY DRIVERS OF TRANSMISSION AND PERSISTENCE OF SARS-COV-2 IN WTD POPULATIONS AND PROVIDE DATA FOR OPTIMIZING RISK-BASED SURVEILLANCE DESIGNS AND DEVELOPING NEW ANALYTICAL TOOLS FOR ONE HEALTH MANAGEMENT. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: AMERICAN AGRICULTURE, HUMAN HEALTH, ANIMALS, AND THE ENVIRONMENT. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

AWARD PURPOSE:  THE REFLECTS A COOPERATIVE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE WILDLIFE SOCIETY (TWS) AND THE UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE (USDA), ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE (APHIS), WILDLIFE SERVICES (WS).  IT ALSO OUTLINES THE MISSION-RELATED GOALS, OBJECTIVES, AND ANTICIPATED ACCOMPLISHMENTS AS WELL AS THE APPROACH FOR THE WILDLIFE SOCIETY PARTNERSHIP, AND THE RELATED ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE PARTIES AS NEGOTIATED.   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:  THE WILDLIFE SOCIETY'S MISSION IS TO INSPIRE, EMPOWER, AND ENABLE WILDLIFE PROFESSIONALS TO SUSTAIN WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITATS THROUGH SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION.   TWS HAS AN ESTABLISHED NETWORK THAT REACHES NEARLY 12,000 WILDLIFE PROFESSIONALS AND STUDENTS. TWS WILL LEVERAGE THIS COMMUNICATIONS NETWORK AND ITS PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES TO ASSIST WILDLIFE SERVICES IN KEEPING ITS STAFF WELL-INFORMED AND TRAINED, WHILE ALSO HELPING THE AGENCY RECRUIT THE BEST AND THE BRIGHTEST FROM BOTH THE PROFESSIONAL AND COLLEGIATE RANKS.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE WILDLIFE SOCIETY HAS AN ESTABLISHED COMMUNICATION NETWORK LEVERAGING PRINT, EMAIL, INTERNET, AND SOCIAL MEDIA RESOURCES AND USES THESE VARIOUS COMMUNICATIONS CHANNELS TO IMPROVE THE SHARING OF WILDLIFE SCIENCE, MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION INFORMATION WITH WILDLIFE PROFESSIONALS AND THE PUBLIC.  THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS NETWORK IS TO SUPPORT THE WORK OF WILDLIFE PROFESSIONALS BY PROVIDING THEM WITH TIMELY INFORMATION ON NEW RESEARCH AND METHODS, BEST PRACTICES, IMPORTANT POLICY ISSUES, AND A WIDE VARIETY OF PERSPECTIVES TO ENCOURAGE DISCUSSION AND INNOVATION, BUT THE NETWORK WILL ALSO PLAY A MAJOR ROLE IN PUBLIC EDUCATION. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES):  THE WILDLIFE SOCIETY PARTNERSHIP IS ALIGNED WITH APHIS' MISSION TO PROTECT THE HEALTH AND VALUE OF AMERICAN AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, USDA APHIS WILL BE POSITIONED AS A PARTNER OF THE WILDLIFE SOCIETY, CONTRIBUTING CONTENT VIA THEIR STAFF AND PRESS RELEASES. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF THE AWARD:  THERE WILL NOT BE SUB-AWARDS FROM THIS AWARD.

AWARD PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO TWO-FOLD. THE FIRST IS TO PRODUCE A WILDLIFE STRIKE SUMMARY AND RISK ANALYSIS REPORT.  THE SECOND IS TO TEACH THE FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION (FAA) AND WILDLIFE SERVICES (WS) HOW TO ACCESS THE DATA AND CREATE THE REPORTS. THE INTENTION IS THAT THE FAA AND WS WILL CREATE THEIR OWN REPORTS FOR FUTURE DATASETS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE COOPERATOR WILL COMPILE AND ANALYZE WILDLIFE AIRCRAFT STRIKE DATA TO PRODUCE THE REPORTS.  IN ADDITION, THE COOPERATOR WILL PREPARE A TRAINING SESSION TO TEACH THE FAA AND WS HOW TO PREPARE THEIR OWN REPORTS.  THE COOPERATOR WILL INCLUDE NOTES ON THE PROCESS AS WELL AS ACCESS TO COMPUTER PROGRAMS AND DATABASES.   DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:  THE FIRST DELIVERABLE IS A FORMAL WILDLIFE STRIKE SUMMARY AND SUPPORTING RISK ANALYSIS REPORTS COVERING THE FIVE-YEAR PERIOD OF 2018 THROUGH 2022.  THE SECOND DELIVERABLE IS THE TRAINING SESSION, COMPLETE WITH NOTES AND SYSTEMS ACCESS. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THE AWARD ARE AVIATION STAKEHOLDERS TO INCLUDE BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION, FAA, USDA WS, AVIATION SAFETY OFFICES, PILOTS AND CREW, AND WILDLIFE STRIKE RESEARCHERS (METHODS DEVELOPMENT, AIRCRAFT ENGINEERING, AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS). THE “GENERAL PUBLIC” WILL HAVE ACCESS TO THE REPORT. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD: THERE WILL NOT BE SUB-AWARDS FROM THIS AWARD.

THE AGREEMENT IS TO SUPPORT COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY TO CONDUCT RESEARCH TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE POTENTIAL ROLE FERAL SWINE MAY PLAY AS MECHANICAL VECTORS OF BACILLUS ANTHRACIS, THE CAUSATIVE AGENT OF ANTHRAX. THIS KNOWLEDGE WILL BE HARNESSED TO IMPROVE DIAGNOSTIC ASSAYS AND PROVIDE KNOWLEDGE TO ADVANCE THE UTILITY OF THE NATIONAL SURVEILLANCE PROGRAM AND TARGETED DISEASE MITIGATION EFFORTS.

SUPPORT COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY TO CONDUCT RESEARCH IN AND AROUND FERAL SWINE WALLOWS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE RISK OF PATHOGEN TR ANSMISSION AND EXPOSURE IN THESE ENVIRONMENTS. THIS KNOWLEDGE WILL BE USED TO IDENTIFY AREAS OF INCREASED RISK FOR PATHOGEN TRANSMISSION BETWEEN FERAL SWINE AND OTHER SPECIES AND TO ENHANCE KNOWLEDGE TO ADVANCE THE UTILITY OF THE NATIONAL SURVEILLANCE PROGRAM AND TARGETED DISEASE MITIGATION EFFORTS.

AWARD PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE RESEARCH/SURVEILLANCE NEEDS FOR EXPLORING THE POTENTIAL FOR WILD PIG WALLOWS TO SERVE AS A SOURCE OF PATHOGEN TRANSMISSION. THESE FINDINGS ARE TO BE USED FOR PROSPECTIVE REGULATORY AND PEST MANAGEMENT PURPOSES.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE RECIPIENT WILL WORK WITH USDA-APHIS-VS AND WS PERSONNEL TO IDENTIFY CURRENT WILD PIG REMOVAL EFFORTS AT FIELD SITES IN THE SOUTHEASTERN US; PERFORM FIELD WORK AT FIELD SITES TO COLLECT SAMPLES AND DATA ON VECTOR COMMUNITIES, MICROBIAL COMMUNITIES, AND PATHOGENS; CONDUCT LABORATORY ANALYSES INCLUDING IDENTIFICATION OF VECTORS AND PATHOGENS FROM DIFFERENT SOURCES; COLLATE LABORATORY DATA AND ANALYZE RESULTS.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE RECIPIENT WILL SUBMIT AN ANNUAL REPORT SUMMARIZING ALL ACTIVITIES AND WILL ATTEMPT TO PUBLISH AT LEAST TWO MANUSCRIPTS SUMMARIZING THE DATA AND INCLUDE USDA-APHIS COLLABORATORS AS COAUTHOR. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): THE NATIONAL FERAL SWINE DAMAGE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, WILDLIFE DISEASE AND EPIDEMIOLOGY SPECIALISTS, SWINE INDUSTRY STAKEHOLDERS.  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES ARE NOT EXPECTED.

AWARD PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO IMPLEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE FERAL SWINE TRANSBOUNDARY WORKING GROUP. THE MIS SION OF THIS GROUP ALIGNS WITH AND ENHANCES THE GOALS OF THE NATIONAL FERAL SWINE DAMAGE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM MAKING THE ORGANIZATIONS SUITABLE PARTNERS.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THIS AGREEMENT WILL ENABLE A FERAL SWINE WORKSHOP ALONGSIDE THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST ECONOMIC REGION ANNUAL SUMMIT AND SUPPORT THE CREATION OF A SQUEAL ON PIGS! BRANDED WEBSITE FOR PUBLIC EDUCATION AND REPORTING OF FERAL SWINE.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE GOALS FOR THE FERAL SWINE WORKSHOP ARE TO PROMOTE THE TOPIC OF FERAL SWINE TO A BROAD AUDIENCE OF STATE AND PROVINCIAL STAFF AND OFFICIALS. TECHNICAL DEMONSTRATIONS WILL EDUCATE FIELD LEVEL STAFF ON FERAL SWINE DAMAGE MANAGEMENT. THE A ‘SQUEAL ON PIGS’ WEBSITE WILL SERVE AS A NORTH AMERICAN HUB FOR PUBLIC REPORTING AND TO FACILITATE INFORMATION SHARING ACROSS BORDERS AND AMONG FERAL SWINE MANAGEMENT ORGANIZATIONS. THE WEBSITE WILL PROVIDE CONTENT ON HOW TO REPORT SIGHTINGS OF FERAL SWINE WITH LINKS TO THE APPROPRIATE STATE/PROVINCIAL WEBSITES. OTHER CONTENT WILL INCLUDE FERAL SWINE IDENTIFICATION, IMPACTS, CONTROL, AND EDUCATION. THE WEBSITE WILL HOST RESOURCES FOR AGENCY PARTNERS, INCLUDING THE ‘SQUEAL ON PIGS’ CAMPAIGN LOGO/GRAPHICS, STYLE GUIDE, AND USAGE GUIDELINES.  INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): KEY BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE STATE AND PROVINCIAL WILDLIFE MANAGERS WHO ARE WORKING TO PREVENT FERAL SWINE INTRODUCTION OR REDUCE FERAL SWINE DAMAGE IN THEIR REGION. THE BROAD PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM THE SUCCESS OF WILDLIFE MANAGERS IN PREVENTING AND REDUCING FERAL SWINE DAMAGE.   SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD: THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST ECONOMIC REGION ORGANIZATION WILL RECEIVE FUNDS FOR WORKSHOP FACILITATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO CONTINUE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A “ONE HEALTH” COLLABORATION AMONG USDA, APHIS, WILDLIFE SERVICES NATIONAL RABIES MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (WS NRMP) AND AUBURN UNIVERSITY (AU) SCHOOL OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE SCIENCES AND COLLEGE OF VETERINARY MEDICINE TO IMPROVE STRATEGIES FOR ENHANCED RABIES SURVEILLANCE (ERS), ORAL RABIES VACCINATION (ORV) MONITORING AND WILDLIFE RABIES MANAGEMENT. THE FOCUS OF THIS MUTUAL ENDEAVOR IS TO PROVIDE NEW AND/OR REFINED DIAGNOSTIC TOOLS FOR ERS IN WILDLIFE AND TO CONDUCT RESEARCH ON VACCINE BAIT UPTAKE ECOLOGY WITH RACCOONS AND OTHER WILDLIFE SPECIES IN ALABAMA TO REFINE ORV BAITING STRATEGIES IN SUPPORT OF THE WS NRMP MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES. APHIS INITIATIVE_PROTECTING NATURAL RESOURCES -IN THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES, IT HAS BEEN SPECULATED THAT WILD PIGS ARE AT LEAST PARTIALLY RESPONSIBLE FOR RECENT DECLINES IN EASTERN WILD TURKEY POPULATIONS.  RESEARCH FOCUSED ON UNDERSTANDING THE IMPACTS OF WILD PIGS ON SPATIAL DYNAMICS OF EASTERN WILD TURKEY, AS WELL AS CONTINUED MONITORING OF PREVIOUS RESEARCH DESIGNED TO EXAMINE IMPACTS OF WILD PIGS ON POPULATIONS OF EASTERN WILD TURKEYS.  THE CONTINUED MONITORING WILL TAKE PLACE WITH PREVIOUSLY STUDIED POPULATIONS AND WILL INVOLVE BIANNUAL POPULATION SURVEYS USING CAMERA TRAPS FOR BOTH WILD PIGS AND EASTERN WILD TURKEYS. THIS EFFORT IS DESIGNED TO EXAMINE HOW TURKEY POPULATIONS RESPOND TO CESSATION OF WILD PIG CONTROL EFFORTS AND BETTER UNDERSTAND THE TIMING AND DEGREE OF POPULATION CHANGE FOLLOWING THIS CESSATION.

THE MISSISSIPPI DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND COMMERCE WILD HOG CONTROL PROGRAM WAS CREATED AS A RESULT OF MISSISSIPPI STATE LEGISLATION PASSED DURING THE 2020 LEGISLATIVE SESSION. THE LEGISLATION AUTHORIZED THE COMMISSIONER OF AGRICULTURE AND COMMERCE TO PROVIDE ASSISTANCE TO LANDOWNERS, FARMERS AND PRODUCERS REGARDING THE MANAGEMENT OF NUISANCE WILDLIFE ON PRIVATE AGRICULTURAL AND FORESTRY LANDS. UNDER THAT AUTHORITY, THE PROGRAM WAS CREATED TO HELP CONTROL WILD HOGS ON PRIVATE LANDS ACROSS THE STATE. THE APPROPRIATED FUNDING IN THIS REQUEST WILL BE USED TO EXPAND THE PROGRAM.  THE GRANT WILL INCREASE ASSISTANCE PROVIDED TO PRIVATE LAND MANAGERS FOR THE REMOVAL OF WILD HOGS THROUGH THE PROGRAM; CREATE AND IMPLEMENT A YOUTH TRAPPING CORPS, WHICH WILL BE A WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM USED TO EDUCATE AND PROFESSIONALLY DEVELOP YOUTH WITH REGARDS TO THE IMPACT OF NUISANCE ANIMALS AND THE IMPORTANCE OF WILD HOG MANAGEMENT ACROSS MISSISSIPPI; AND CREATE AND IMPLEMENT A WILD HOG TRAPPING COST-SHARE PROGRAM FOR PRIVATE AGRICULTURAL AND FOR ESTRY LANDS IN MISSISSIPPI.  OVERALL, THIS FUNDING WILL ALLOW THE PROGRAM TO EXPAND AND CONTINUE ITS EFFORTS FOR MANY YEARS TO COME. ALTHOUGH THIS IS A ONE-YEAR AGREEMENT, THE BENEFITS WILL CONTINUE FOR AT LEAST 5 YEARS. A MINIMUM OF 86 TRAPS AND ASSOCIATED CONTROL EQUIPMENT WILL BE USED TO REMOVE WILD HOGS FROM THE LANDSCAPE OVER THE LIFE EXPECTANCY OF THE TRAPS AND EQUIPMENT. THE NUMBER OF CONTROL EVENTS WILL BE DEPENDENT UPON WILD HOG POPULATION ABUNDANCE AND PUBLIC DEMAND. TECHNICAL GUIDANCE AND TRAINING WILL BE PROVIDED TO A MINIMUM OF 200 PEOPLE ANNUALLY BUT WILL LIKELY APPROACH 500. THE ESTIMATED NUMBER OF WILD HOGS TO BE REMOVED IS UNKNOWN BUT ACTUAL REMOVAL NUMBERS WILL BE REPORTED.  THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE CITIZENS OF MISSISSIPPI AND NEIGHBORING STATES.  SUBAWARDEES WILL INCLUDE FUNDING TO SCHOOLS AND YOUTH ORGANIZATIONS FOR THE YOUTH TRAPPING CORPS, AS WELL AS FUNDING FOR THE PRIVATE LANDS COST SHARE PROGRAM.

1. AWARD PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE (CWD) SAMPLE DIAGNOSTICS FOR WILD CERVID SAMPLES SUBMITTED BY NATIVE AMERICAN TRIBES.2. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE CSU VETERINARY DIAGNOSTIC LABORATORY, A NATIONAL ANIMAL HEALTH LABORATORY NETWORK (NAHLN) AFFILIATED LABORATORY, WILL PROVIDE THE CWD DIAGNOSTICS AND RESULTS REPORTING FOR THE WILD CERVID SAMPLES SUBMITTED BY TRIBES.3. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE GOAL OF THIS AGREEMENT IS FOR CSU VETERINARY DIAGNOSTIC LABORATORY TO PROVIDE TRIBES WITH TEST RESULTS FOR CWD MONITORING AND SURVEILLANCE BEING CONDUCTED ON TRIBAL LANDS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND WORK FOR APPLYING LANDSCAPEGENOMICS TO INFER CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE TRANSMISSION CORRIDORS ANDINFORM MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES IN WESTERN KENTUCKY AND TENNESSEE.  THEGOAL IS TO IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE-AFFECTEDWILD CERVID POPULATIONS.  RECIPIENT WILL CONDUCT REDUCED REPRESENTATIONSEQUENCING TO EVALUATE THE SPATIAL POPULATION STRUCTURE AND GENETICCONNECTIVITY AMONG WHITE-TAILED DEER POPULATIONS IN WESTERN KENTUCKY ANDTENNESSEE; APPLY LANDSCAPE RESISTANCE MAPPING TO GENOMICS DATASET TODETERMINE HOW LANDSCAPE FEATURES INFLUENCE THE POPULATION STRUCTURE ANDGENE FLOW OF WHITE-TAILED DEER IN THIS REGION; AND CONDUCT SEQUENCING OFTHE PRNP (GENE) PRION PROTEIN GENE IN WESTERN KENTUCKY AND TENNESSEEWHITE-TAILED DEER TO ASSESS THE SPATIAL HETEROGENEITY IN PRNPPOLYMORPHISMS TO DETERMINE THE PREVALENCE AND CONFIGURATION OFHIGH-SUSCEPTIBILITY GENOTYPES ACROSS THE LANDS.  DATA WILL BE AVAILABLETO PROJECT PARTNERS AND WILL BE UPLOADED TO THENATIONAL CENTER FORBIOTECHNOLOGY INFORMATION AS AN OPEN-ACCESS RESOURCE FOR ALL GENETICISTSAT THE COMPLETION OF THIS PROJECT.  RESULTS WILL BE PRESENTED ATRELEVANT SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCES AND WORKING GROUP MEETINGS AND WILL BEPUBLISHED VIA MANUSCRIPTS IN PEER-REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS.  THEINTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE RESEARCHERS AND MANAGERS AFFECTED BY CHRONICWASTING DISEASE IN WESTERN KENTUCKY AND TENNESSEE, AS WELL AS STAKEHOLDERS IN OTHER AREAS.  UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY WILL PROVIDE ASSISTANCE IN COLLECTION OF SAMPLES, SAMPLE PROCESSING, AND DATAANALYSIS FOR THE PROJECT. THEIR PERSONNEL WILL FACILITATE THE ANALYSISTHAT RECIPIENT DOES NOT HAVE THE CAPACITY TO COMPLETE AT THIS TIME, BOTHIN FACILITIES AND EXPERTISE. THEY HAVE AGREED TO CLOSELY COLLABORATEWITH THE KENTUCKY AND TENNESSEE WILDLIFE AGENCY COLLABORATORS IN THEPROJECT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND A PROJECT FOR FIELD EVALUATION OFTRAINED CANINE DETECTION OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINATION CAUSED BYCHRONIC WASTING DISEASE INFECTION.  THE GOAL IS TO IMPROVE THEMANAGEMENT OF WILD CERVID CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE-AFFECTED AREAS.  INTHE LABORATORY, THE RECIPIENT WILL TRAIN AND TEST TWO DOGS TO DETECT ANDDISCRIMINATE SOIL SAMPLES COLLECTED FROM HIGHLY ENDEMIC AREAS ANDCONFIRMED BY LABORATORY TESTING TO CONTAIN CHRONIC WASTING DISEASEPRIONS IN COMPARISON TO SOIL SAMPLES FOUND IN TENNESSEE WHERE THERE ISZERO PREVALENCE OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE; IN THE FIELD, TRANSITION TWOTRAINED DOGS FROM DETECTION AND DISCRIMINATION OF SOIL SAMPLES IN BOXES,TO SOIL SAMPLES PLACED ON ASPHALT. THE SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED FROMHIGHLY ENDEMIC AREAS THAT ARE CONFIRMED TO CONTAIN CHRONIC WASTINGDISEASE PRIONS IN COMPARISON TO SOIL SAMPLES FOUND IN TENNESSEE WHERETHERE IS ZERO PREVALENCE OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE; AND IN THE FIELD,TRAIN AND TEST TWO DOGS TO DETECT AND DISCRIMINATE POTENTIAL AREAS OFENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINATION CAUSED BY CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE INFECTIONAT CERVID GATHERING LOCATIONS IN AREAS WHERE CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE HASNOT BEEN DETECTED. TEST SITES HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED BY UTILIZATION OFTRAIL CAMERAS THROUGH A SEPARATE STUDY.  RESEARCH CLEARLY PREDICTS THATCANINE BIODETECTORS CAN BE TRAINED TO IDENTIFY POPULATIONS AND/ORINDIVIDUALS INFECTED WITH CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE VIA DETECTION OF FECESODORS. SUCH A TOOL MAY ALSO PROVE USEFUL IN IDENTIFYING POTENTIAL“HOT-SPOT” AREAS ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE THAT SERVE AS CHRONIC WASTINGDISEASE PRION RESERVOIRS AND POTENTIAL TRANSMISSION SITES DUE TOCONTAMINATION CAUSED BY INFECTED CERVIDS. ALL DATA FILES WILL BEAVAILABLE FROM THE HTTPS://WWW.FS.USDA.GOV/RDS/ARCHIVE/ DATABASE.  THEUSE OF CANINE BIODETECTORS IN THE DETECTION OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASEENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINATION WOULD PROVIDE HUNTERS, LANDOWNERS, MEATPROCESSORS, TAXIDERMISTS AND STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES A RAPID TESTINGAPPROACH TO THE DETECTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASEPRION RESERVOIRS.  A SUBAWARD WILL BE ISSUED WITH COLORADO STATEUNIVERSITY (CSU) TO MAINTAIN, TRAIN, AND TEST CANINE BIODETECTORS, ANDWITH THE TENNESSEE WILDLIFE FOUNDATION TO ADMINISTER THE GRANT CONTRACTSBETWEEN CSU AND THE RECIPIENT AND HIRE A PART-TIME TECHNICIAN FOR FIELDWORK.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO STUDY FIRE AS A TOOL FOR REMEDIATION OFPRION-CONTAMINATED LANDSCAPES.  THE GOAL IS TO IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT OFWILD CERVID CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE-AFFECTED AREAS.  RECIPIENT WILLMEASURE REDUCTION IN PRION SEEDING ACTIVITY IN BURNED SOIL AS A FUNCTIONOF DEPTH AND BURN TEMPERATURE; MEASURE REDUCTION IN PRION SEEDINGACTIVITY IN BURNED SOIL AS A FUNCTION OF TIME AND REPEATED BURN CYCLES;MEASURE REDUCTION IN PRION SEEDING ACTIVITY IN BURNED SOIL AS A FUNCTIONOF SOIL TEXTURAL CLASS; AND MEASURE REDUCTION IN PRION SEEDING ACTIVITYIN BURNED SOILS SOURCED FROM NATURALLY CONTAMINATED SITES.  THIS WORKWILL BE PRINCIPALLY DISSEMINATED THROUGH ONE OR MORE MANUSCRIPTS INPEER-REVIEWED JOURNALS. THIS WILL ENSURE THAT RELEVANT DECISION MAKERSIN RESEARCH INSTITUTIONS, STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, AND OTHER EXPERTCAPACITIES WILL BE AWARE OF THE FINDINGS.  THIS WORK WILL FIND AUDIENCEWITH STATE/FEDERAL AGENCIES RESPONSIBLE FOR MANAGEMENT OF CHRONICWASTING DISEASE ENDEMIC AREAS. THOUGH PRINCIPALLY AIMED AT WILD CERVIDPOPULATIONS, THIS WORK WILL LIKELY ALSO FIND AN AUDIENCE WITH THEPRIVATE LANDOWNERS, AS A MEANS FOR CLEANUP OF CONTAMINATED SITES. SUBAWARD WILL BE ISSUED WITH UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN (THROUGH THETENNESSEE WILDLIFE FOUNDATION) FOR LABORATORY INVESTIGATION OF RESPONSESOF PRION CHARACTERISTICS TO APPLICATION OF FIRE; AND ALSO WITH THETENNESSEE WILDLIFE FOUNDATION FOR CONTRACT AND GRANTS ADMINISTRATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND THE PROJECT FOR DEVELOPING GENETICAPPROACHES FOR SUSTAINABLE LONG-TERM MONITORING AND MODELING CHRONICWASTING DISEASE SPREAD IN WHITE-TAILED DEER.  THE GOAL IS TO DEVELOPAND/OR APPLICATION OF PREDICTIVE GENETICS FOR WILD CERVIDS.  THERECIPIENT WILL DESIGN AND VALIDATE A STANDARDIZED COST-EFFECTIVE SNP(SINGLE NUCLEOTIDE POLYMORPHISM) SCREENING PANEL (GT-SEQ) TO PROMOTESUSTAINABLE LONG-TERM GENETIC MONITORING IN ARKANSAS; CREATE ASTANDARDIZED WORKFLOW AND CUSTOM BIOINFORMATICS PIPELINES TO RAPIDLYPROCESS SNP-DATA FROM GT-SEQ OUTPUT; GENERATE ‘BEST-PRACTICES’ FOR THEUSE AND APPLICATION OF MACHINE-LEARNING GEOLOCATION ANALYSIS WITH SNPDATA; DEVELOP NOVEL STATISTICAL AND COMPUTATIONAL APPROACHES TO MODELLANDSCAPE RESISTANCE AND INDIVIDUAL DISPERSAL IN SPECIES WITH HISTORIESOF TRANSLOCATION; AND DISSEMINATE RESEARCH FINDINGS AND DEVELOPEDRESOURCES THROUGH OPEN-SOURCE SOFTWARE (E.G., R PACKAGES), PRESENTATIONSAND PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS.  THE RECIPIENTWILL CONDUCT MEETINGS ANDWEBINARS FOR STAKEHOLDERS INTERESTED IN USING THE TOOLS, WORKFLOWS, ANDSOFTWARE TO INFORM MANAGEMENT OF WHITE-TAILED DEER AND CHRONIC WASTINGDISEASE RISK IN THEIR JURISDICTION. THE RESEARCH WILL ALSO BE PRESENTEDAT AN INTERNATIONAL SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCE AND PUBLISHED IN OPEN-ACCESS,PEER-REVIEWED JOURNALS.  GEOLOCATION REPORTS WILL BE PREPARED ANDPROVIDED TO RECIPIENT STAFF RESPONSIBLE FOR CHRONIC WASTING DISEASEMANAGEMENT DECISIONS. LANDSCAPE RESISTANCE AND DISPERSAL INFORMATIONWILL BE SUMMARIZED AND VISUALLY DISPLAYED AND PROVIDED TO STATE AGENCYSTAFF FOR USE IN CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE AND WHITE-TAILED DEERMANAGEMENT. THE PRIMARY BENEFICIARIES OF THE INFORMATION PRODUCED BYTHIS PROJECT WOULD BE THE RECIPIENT’S CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE MANAGEMENTTEAM WHO WOULD IMPLEMENT INFORMATION GAINED WITHIN FOR CHRONIC WASTINGDISEASE MANAGEMENT PLANS AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. RESULTS WILL ALSO BEGREATLY BENEFICIAL TO OTHERS WHO WANT TO USE TOOLS FOR UTILIZINGWHITE-TAILED DEER GENETIC DATA TO AID IN CHRONIC WASTING DISEASEMANAGEMENT.  A SUBAGREEMENT WILL BE ISSUED WITH THE UNIVERSITY OFARKANSAS TO CONDUCT THIS PROJECT, DUE TO EXPERTISE OF STAFF ANDFACILITIES/EQUIPMENT.

THIS PROJECT DESCRIBES A SURVEY IN WHICH THE INFORMATION ABOUTMOTIVATIONS, SOCIAL NORMS, AND AN EVALUATION OF THE SAMPLE SUBMISSIONPROCESS FOR TESTING WILL BE SOLICITED FROM SUCCESSFUL DEER HUNTERS, ASWELL AS REASONS FOR NOT SUBMITTING BY SUCCESSFUL DEER HUNTERS THAT DONOT SUBMIT SAMPLES FOR TESTING.  RECIPIENT WILL DETERMINE MOTIVATIONSAND SOCIAL NORMS FOR CONTINUED CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE TESTING,SATISFACTION WITH THE SUBMISSION PROCESS, AND KNOWLEDGE AND RISKPERCEPTION OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE IN NORTH CAROLINA.  THE RESULTS OFTHIS PROJECT WILL CULMINATE IN A SPECIFIC DATA REPORT ANDRECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPROVEMENTS TO SAMPLING TECHNIQUES AND OUTREACHMATERIALS FOR DEER HUNTERS. THESE RECOMMENDATIONS WILL BE USED BY THERECIPIENT TO UNDERSTAND THE DEER HUNTERS OF NORTH CAROLINA AND TO MAKEADJUSTMENTS TO CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE RESPONSE AND MANAGEMENTACTIVITIES.  THESE RESULTS WILL ALSO PROVIDE INFORMATION FOR EDUCATIONALMATERIALS TARGETED TOWARDS DEER HUNTERS TO SOLICIT COMPLIANCE ANDCOOPERATION AND EXPLAIN THE LONG-TERM IMPACT OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASEON HUNTING IN NORTH CAROLINA.  NORTH CAROLINA DEER HUNTERS WILL BENEFITFROM THE RESULTS OF THIS SURVEY PROJECT. THIS AUDIENCE IS ACTIVELYENGAGED IN WHITE-TAILED DEER MANAGEMENT, AND CARES ABOUT THE CONTINUEDHEALTH OF THE HERD. THE RECIPIENT WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS INITIALEVALUATION OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE SAMPLING PROCEDURES AND A BETTERUNDERSTANDING OF NOT ONLY DEER HUNTERS CHRONIC WASTING DISEASEKNOWLEDGE, CONCERNS AND COMPLIANCE, BUT WHY HUNTERS STATEWIDE SUBMITSAMPLES FOR TESTING.  THERE ARE NO KNOWN SUBAWARDEES.

THIS STUDY AIMS TO COMPILE A DIRECTORY OF POLICIES ENACTED BY STATEWILDLIFE AGENCIES AIMED AT SLOWING THE SPREAD OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASEIN NORTH AMERICA.  RECIPIENT WILL CONDUCT A REVIEW AND ANALYSIS OF STATEWILDLIFE AGENCY POLICIES AIMED AT SLOWING OR STOPPING THE SPREAD OFCHRONIC WASTING DISEASE, INCLUDING A REVIEW OF CURRENT AND PAST CHRONICWASTING DISEASE POLICIES AND REGULATIONS, DEVELOPMENT OF A METRIC FOREVALUATING COMPLIANCE WITH CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE POLICIES, AND ANANALYSIS OF POLICY EFFECTIVENESS.  THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK WILL BE USEDBY THE RECIPIENT TO MAKE MORE INFORMED, DATA-DRIVEN POLICY DECISIONS.THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE APPLIED RESEARCH THAT STATE AGENCIES CAN USE FORPRACTICAL POLICY DEVELOPMENT. IT WILL IMPROVE UPON CURRENT GUIDANCE BYPROVIDING RECOMMENDATIONS ON AGENCY POLICIES, RATHER THAN MANAGEMENTACTIONS ALONE. THIS KNOWLEDGE WILL HELP THE RECIPIENT AND OTHER STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES TO BE MORE EFFECTIVE IN THEIR POLICY AND RULEMAKING BY DEVELOPING EVALUATIVE METRICS FOR MEASURING COMPLIANCE ANDDETERMINING SUCCESS.  THE RECIPIENT AND OTHER AGENCIES INTERESTED INCHRONIC WASTING DISEASE MANAGEMENT WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS POLICY REVIEW.STATE AGENCIES CURRENTLY DEVELOPING OR EXPLORING CHRONIC WASTING DISEASERESPONSE PLANS OR STATES WHO HAVE NOT YET FOUND THE DISEASE WITHIN THEIRBORDERS WILL ALSO BENEFIT FROM THE DELIVERABLES INCLUDING POLICYRECOMMENDATIONS AND AN APPLICABLE METRIC FOR ASSESSING POLICY EFFICACY. THERE ARE NO KNOWN SUBAWARDEES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND WORK FOR PARTNERING WITHTAXIDERMISTS TO EXPAND CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE SURVEILLANCE STATEWIDE INMINNESOTA.  THE GOAL IS TO IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT OF CHRONIC WASTINGDISEASE-AFFECTED WILD CERVID POPULATIONS.  RECIPIENT WILL PARTNER WITH ANON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION TO FACILITATE A STATEWIDE CHRONIC WASTINGDISEASE PARTNER SURVEILLANCE PROGRAM USING LICENSED TAXIDERMISTS. THISWILL INCREASE SURVEILLANCE AND SAMPLING CAPACITY FOR CHRONIC WASTINGDISEASE SURVEILLANCE IN WILD CERVIDS IN MINNESOTA. AT THE COMPLETION OFTHIS PROJECT, THE RECIPIENT AND MINNESOTA CONSERVATION FEDERATION WILLGENERATE A SUMMARY THAT DESCRIBES THE SUCCESSES AND FAILURES OF THEPROJECT, AFTER POTENTIALLY CONDUCTING A SURVEY OF TAXIDERMISTS TODETERMINE WHAT THEY CONSIDERED TO BE PROS AND CONS OF THIS PROGRAM. THISSUMMARY WOULD BE AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST TO FISH AND WILDLIFEASSOCIATIONS, STATE AGENCIES, TRIBAL ORGANIZATIONS, AND NON-PROFITENTITIES. IT WILL OUTLINE THE ASPECTS OF THE PROJECTTHAT WORKED WELLAND THE ASPECTS OF THE PROJECT THAT MAY NEED TO BE RE-IMAGINED. WHITE-TAILED DEER ARE A PUBLIC TRUST RESOURCE IN MINNESOTA, ANDPOPULATIONS THAT WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS WORK INCLUDE ALL RESIDENTS,TRIBAL ORGANIZATIONS, AND DEER HUNTERS OF MINNESOTA. FURTHERMORE,HUNTERS THAT VISIT THESE TAXIDERMISTS OUTSIDE OF THE RECIPIENT’SESTABLISHED CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE ZONES WILL HAVE ACCESS TO FREESAMPLING AND TESTING OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE FIRST TIME IN MINNESOTA’SHISTORY. THE RECIPIENT WILL BENEFIT BY GATHERING INFORMATION ON THEDISEASE STATUS OF DEER POPULATIONS THAT HAVE NOT BEEN TESTED FOR CHRONICWASTING DISEASE SINCE THE MID-2000’S. IN ADDITION, THIS WILL PROVIDEIMPORTANT CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE SURVEILLANCE AROUND TRIBAL LANDS, ASMANY TRIBES VIEW CERVIDS AS IMPORTANT CULTURAL FOOD SOURCES.  MINNESOTACONSERVATION FEDERATION WILL ASSIST IN THE RECRUITMENT AND PAYMENT FORTAXIDERMIST-COLLECTED SAMPLES. THE RECIPIENT WILL ALSO ESTABLISH ASUBAWARD WITH COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY, WHO WILL UTILIZE AN EXISTINGAGREEMENT WITH COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY (A CERTIFIED LAB) TO TESTCHRONIC WASTING DISEASE SAMPLES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND A PROJECT FOR BETA TESTING POOLEDSAMPLING THRESHOLDS AGAINST TRADITIONAL CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE TESTING. THE GOAL IS TO CONDUCT RESEARCH ON AMPLIFICATION ASSAYS IN WILD CERVIDSAND OTHER NEW TEST METHODS.  RECIPIENT WILL COMPARE THE PERFORMANCE OFTESTING POOLED SAMPLES AT A 1:4 AND 1:9 DILUTION OF THE POSITIVE BYENZYME-LINKED IMMUNOASSAY (ELISA) TO TRADITIONAL TESTING WITH ELISA VIAUSE OF PAIRED RPLN (RETROPHARYNGEAL LYMPH NODE); COMPARE THE PERFORMANCEOF TESTING POOLED SAMPLES AT A 1:24 OR 1:49 DILUTION OF THE POSITIVE BYRT-QUIC (REAL-TIME QUAKING-INDUCED CONVERSION) TO TRADITIONAL TESTINGWITH ELISA VIA USE OF PAIRED RPLN; EVALUATE THE TECHNICIAN TIME ANDAMOUNT OF CONSUMABLES REQUIRED TO PREPARE THESE DIFFERENT DILUTIONS FORELISA AND RT-QUIC; AND DETERMINE WHICH POOLING THRESHOLDS MAXIMIZESENSITIVITY AND FUNCTIONALITY FOR SCREENING REAL-WORLD SAMPLES BY ELISAAND RT-QUIC.  RESULTS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE SHARED WITH CHRONICWASTING DISEASE COORDINATORS IN OTHER STATES, ESPECIALLY THOSE IN THEMIDWEST ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES, AND PARTICIPANTS INTHE NORTH AMERICAN INTERDISCIPLINARY CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE RESEARCHCONSORTIUM. GUIDANCE ON SAMPLE PREPARATION AND POOLING PROCEDURES WILLBE MADE FREELY AVAILABLE.  BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE CHRONIC WASTING DISEASEIN IOWA AND ELSEWHERE.  A SUBCONTRACT WITH IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY COLLEGEOF VETERINARY MEDICINE IS ESSENTIAL TO CONDUCT PRION RESEARCH AT THEUNIVERSITY, WHICH HAS CRITICAL EXPERTISE IN VIROLOGY AND DIAGNOSTICS OFHUMAN AND VETERINARY IMPORT AND WILL BE AN ESSENTIAL PARTNER FORDEVELOPING STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES TO IMPLEMENT POOLED CHRONICWASTING DISEASE TESTING AT VETERINARY DIAGNOSTIC LABORATORIES IN THEFUTURE.  ALSO, A SERVICE AGREEMENT WITH THE IOWA STATE UNIVERSITYVETERINARY DIAGNOSTIC LABORATORY IS NECESSARY FOR ANNUAL CHRONIC WASTINGDISEASE SURVEILLANCE ACTIVITIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND STATEWIDE SURVEILLANCE OF CHRONICWASTING DISEASE IN MARYLAND.  HE GOAL IS TO IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT OFCHRONIC WASTING DISEASE-AFFECTED WILD CERVID POPULATIONS.  RECIPIENTWILL EXPAND CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE SURVEILLANCE IN MARYLAND ANDSAMPLING EFFORTS; DEVELOP AN EFFICIENT SAMPLE COLLECTION WORKFLOW; HELPDEFINE THE NATIONAL ANIMAL HEALTH LABORATORY NETWORK (NAHLN) ELECTRONICMESSAGING STANDARD FOR CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE TESTING IN CERVIDS; ANDUSE THE NAHLN ELECTRONIC MESSAGING SYSTEM TO TRANSMIT CHRONIC WASTINGDISEASE TEST RESULTS TO THE ENTERPRISE MESSAGING SERVICE AND INGESTCHRONIC WASTING DISEASE MESSAGES INTO THE CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE DATAWAREHOUSE.  A SUMMARY OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE TESTING RESULTS WILL BEMADE PUBLIC BY THE RECIPIENT, AND COUNTY AND MUNICIPAL AUTHORITIES MAYBE ADVISED ON ACTIONS THEY CAN TAKE TO LIMIT THE SPREAD OF CHRONICWASTING DISEASE BEYOND THE SCOPE OF THE RECIPIENT. ALL TOOLS ANDSOFTWARE DEVELOPED THROUGHOUT THE DURATION OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILLBE MADE AVAILABLE TO ALL CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE DATA WAREHOUSEPARTNERS. ALL WILDLIFE AGENCIES USING THE CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE DATAWAREHOUSE FOR CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE SURVEILLANCE WILL BE ABLE TO HAVETHEIR CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE TEST RESULTS TRANSMITTED DIRECTLY TO THEWAREHOUSE. THE FUNCTIONALITY AND EFFICIENCIES GAINED THROUGH THEPROPOSED PROJECT WILL INCREASE SURVEILLANCE DATA AND KNOWLEDGE SHARINGBY LOWERING AND ELIMINATING TECHNOLOGY BARRIERS. IMPROVED DATA SHARINGCAN LEAD TO IMPROVED SITUATIONAL AWARENESS AND IS THE FOUNDATION FORSCIENTIFICALLY SOUND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.  THE RECIPIENT WILLDIRECTLY BENEFIT FROM THE INCREASED SURVEILLANCE AND IMPROVED DATAMANAGEMENT. THE FUNDING AGENCY WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT FROM THE UPDATEDMESSAGING SYSTEM DEVELOPED FOR CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE. STATE WILDLIFEAGENCIES WILL BENEFIT FROM THE EFFICIENCY AND DATA INTEGRITY GAINED BYELECTRONIC MESSAGING OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE RESULTS DIRECTLY TO THECHRONIC WASTING DISEASE DATA WAREHOUSE. CONSEQUENTLY, THE IMPROVED DATATRANSMISSION PROCESSES WILL ALLOW THE CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE PARTNERSTO IMPROVE INFORMATION SHARING BETWEEN STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES, AS WELLAS ALL STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES INTERESTED IN MITIGATING THE EFFECTSOF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE ON WILD AND CAPTIVE CERVIDS.  CORNELL WILDLIFE HEALTH LAB WILL ASSIST IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A STATEWIDE SURVEILLANCE PROGRAM IN MARYLAND; THEY WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT ON THEDEVELOPMENT OF NEW TECHNOLOGY FOR DATA MANAGEMENT AND IMPROVED WORKFLOW;AND THEY WILL TAKE LEAD ON IMPROVING DATA RETRIEVAL AND DATA SHARING. DJ CASE <(>&<)> ASSOCIATES WILL BE PROVIDING ASSISTANCE TO CORNELLWILDLIFE HEALTH LAB ON ALL ASPECTS OF SOFTWARE AND DATA WAREHOUSEDEVELOPMENT, AND WILL BE INTEGRAL IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A SYSTEM TOAUTOMATICALLY RETRIEVE CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE TEST RESULTS AND IMPROVEWORKFLOW.

THEMEMBERS OF THE WILDLIFE SOCIETY MANAGE, CONSERVE, AND STUDY WILDLIFEPOPULATIONS AND HABITATS. BUT, THERE ARE KNOWLEDGE GAPS INUNDERSTANDING THE SCOPE OF THE FOOD SAFETY RISK FROM THE CONTINUEDEXPANSION OF FERAL SWINE IN DIFFERENT GEOGRAPHICAL REGIONS. WE PROPOSETO CONDUCT A MULTI-REGIONAL SURVEY OF FOODBORNE PATHOGEN CARRIAGE INFERAL SWINE NEAR HUMAN FOOD CROPS, AND IDENTIFY POTENTIAL SEASONAL ANDENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS ASSOCIATED WITH PREVALENCE. APHIS_INITIATIVE- HUMAN SAFETY:  TO INVESTIGATE QUESTIONS RELATED TO THEIMPACTS OF WILD PIGS ON WATER QUALITY AND PATHOGEN TRANSMISSION INWATER, AS THE RISKS TO SOCIETY ARE NEEDED.  DESPITE RECENT ADVANCES INOUR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW WILD PIGS MAY IMPACT WATER QUALITY, MUCHREMAINS UNKNOWN. THERE ARE STRONG INDICATIONS THAT THE MAGNITUDE ANDSEVERITY OF PIG IMPACTS TO WATER LIKELY VARY DEPENDING ON STREAMCHARACTERISTICS AND PHYSIOGRAPHY, WE LACK THE INFORMATION NECESSARY TOACCURATELY PREDICT AND ANTICIPATE WATER PROBLEMS IN SPECIFIC INSTANCES.GIVEN THE POTENTIAL FOR WILD PIGS TO ACT AS ZOONOTIC DISEASE VECTORS,OUR LEVEL OF KNOWLEDGE CONCERNING WATERBORNE DISEASE TRANSMISSIONASSOCIATED WITH PIGS IS VERY INADEQUATE. AS WILD PIG POPULATIONSCONTINUE TO EXPAND, THE RISKS TO SOCIETY RELATED TO INADEQUATEINFORMATION CONCERNING THESE QUESTIONS BECOMES MORE ACUTE. THE GENERALGOAL IS TO INVESTIGATE AND CLARIFY THE INFORMATION GAPS IN ORDER TOBETTER UNDERSTAND THESE ANIMALS AND THEIR INTERACTIONS WITH SURFACEWATERS AS WELL AS HOW THEY MAY BE CONTROLLED.

APHIS INITIATIVE_PROTECTING AGRICULTURE. THE UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OFAGRICULTURE HAS IMPLEMENTED A NATIONAL RESPONSE TO REDUCE, AND IN SOMEAREAS ELIMINATE, THE DAMAGES INFLICTED BY WILD INVASIVE PIGS.  THE FIRSTOBJECTIVE OF THIS STUDY IS TO HAVE A COMPREHENSIVE, SYSTEMATICEVALUATION OF STATE POLICIES AND LAWS RELATED TO FERAL SWINE, INCLUDINGBUT NOT LIMITED TO ANY POLICIES AND LAWS RELATED TO DISPOSITION OF LIVEFERAL SWINE AND FERAL SWINE CARCASSES. BY RESEARCHING AND ANALYZING THECURRENT STATUTES, REGULATIONS, AND POLICIES CONCERNING FERAL SWINE FORFIFTY (50) STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES, THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILLPROVIDE GENERAL RECOMMENDATIONS THAT WILL HELP THEM TO MORE EFFECTIVELYCONTROL DISEASES OF FERAL SWINE SUCH AS AFRICAN SWINE FEVER (ASF),CLASSICAL SWINE FEVER (CSF), AND FOOT-AND-MOUTH DISEASE (FMD).

DAMAGE MANAGEMENT AND ELIMINATION EFFORTS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED WITHTRAPPING, AND GROUND SHOOTING. TRAIL CAMERAS WILL BE USED TO MONITOR HOGPRESENCE AND DETERMINE TRAP LOCATIONS. TRAP SITES WILLTHEN BE PRE‐BAITED WITH SHELLED CORN AND MONITORED WITH A TRAIL CAMERA.WIRELESS CAMERAS WILL BE USED WHERE FEASIBLE TO ALLOW FOR FEWER SITEVISITS AND REDUCED COST. AS SOON AS HOGS START CONSUMING BAIT, A TRAP ORTRAPPING COMPONENTS WILL BE INTRODUCED UNTIL THE ENTIRE TRAP IS COMPLETEAND SET. TRAPPING WILL CONTINUE AT EACH SITE UNTIL THERE IS NO LONGERACTIVITY AND NEW LOCATION WILL BE SELECTED. BLOOD AND HAIR SAMPLES MAYBE COLLECTED FROM ADULT FERAL HOGS THAT ARE CAPTURED AND EUTHANIZED INACCORDANCE WITH CURRENT APHIS DISEASE SAMPLING PROTOCOLS AND DIRECTIVESIN CONJUNCTION WITH FUNDING AGENCY PROGRAMS. TARGETED MARKETING EFFORTSWILL OCCUR THAT PROMOTE THE PROJECT AND ENCOURAGE LANDOWNERPARTICIPATION WITHIN THE PROJECT AREA. FERAL SWINE PRESENCE/ABSENCE DATAWILL BE GENERATED WITH RESPECT TO USGS 12‐DIGIT HYDROLOGIC UNITS. THISWILL ENHANCE CONTROL EFFORTS AND HELP DIRECT RESOURCES TO AREAS OFGREATEST CONCERN AND ALLOW FOR REPORTING OF RESULTS.  THE INTENDEDBENEFICIARIES ARE THE CITIZENS OF ARKANSAS AND NEIGHBORING STATES. THERE WILL BE NO KNOWN SUBRECIPIENTS.

AP22WSER0000C002, SHANNON FENNELL; WS METHODS DEVELOPMENT INITIATIVE, BLACK VULTURE NEST SUCCESS, FLEDGLING MOVEMENT AND SURVIVAL; BLACK VULTURES (CORAGYPS ATRATUS) ARE A KNOWN ISSUE WITHIN AGRICULTURAL AND SUBURBAN/URBAN ENVIRONMENTS BUT LITTLE IS UNDERSTOOD RELATIVE TO THEIR POPULATION STATUS, LIFE HISTORY TRAITS, AND MOVEMENTS WITHIN THE LANDSCAPE. TO ADEQUATELY DETERMINE THE POTENTIAL FOR MULTIPLE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES TO DEAL WITH THE SPECIES AND THE VULTURE-HUMAN CONFLICTS THAT EXIST AND APPEAR TO BE INCREASING, MORE INFORMATION IS NEEDED TO ASSESS THESE GAPS IN THE KNOWLEDGE OF THE SPECIES. PROJECT PERSONNEL PROPOSE THE CONTINUATION OF A PROJECT INVOLVING BLACK VULTURE NEST MONITORING AND GPS TELEMETRY OF FLEDGLING VULTURES TO FILL SOME OF THE AREAS IN WHICH THEY LACK PROPER PARAMETER ESTIMATES ON THE POPULATION OR THEIR BEHAVIORS. SPECIFICALLY, THE OBJECTIVES/DELIVERABLES ARE 1 . DETERMINE THE FATE OF BLACK VULTURE NESTS, INCLUDING IDENTIFICATION OF NEST PREDATORS WITHIN THE MID-SOUTH; 2. OBTAIN NEST SURVIVAL AND CHICK TO FLEDGLING RECRUITMENT ESTIMATES; 3. ESTIMATE SURVIVAL, HOME RANGE, AND MOVEMENT CHARACTERISTICS OF FLEDGLING BLACK VULTURES.  TO ACCOMPLISH THESE GOALS, PROJECT PERSONNEL WILL DEPLOY CAMERAS AT BLACK VULTURE NEST LOCATIONS IDENTIFIED IN SPRING 2020 AND 2021, PENDING RE-NESTING, AND ADDITIONAL NESTS LOCATED IN SPRING 2022. UPON FINDING A NEST, DATA RELATIVE TO THE NUMBER OF EGGS AND APPROXIMATE AGES WILL BE COLLECTED AND A TRAIL CAMERA WILL BE POSITIONED TO CAPTURE ANY EVENT THAT WOULD CAUSE NEST FAILURE OR CHICK MORTALITY. A SUBSET (N=10) OF FLEDGLING BIRDS WERE EQUIPPED WITH A GSM 20-70 GPS TRANSMITTER JUST PRIOR TO LEAVING THE NEST SITE. THESE TRANSMITTERS ARE CAPABLE OF COLLECTING HUNDREDS OF LOCATIONS DAILY BASED ON ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS AND CAN REMAIN FUNCTIONAL FOR A PERIOD UP TO 4 YEARS. THIS DATA WILL BE COMPILED AND ANALYZED ON A SEASONAL BASIS TO ESTIMATE HOME RANGE, MOVEMENT RATES, HABITAT USE, AND SURVIVAL. IF TRANSMITTER LIFE ALLOWS, PERSONNEL WILL ALSO BE ABLE TO DETERMINE THE AGE AT WHICH THIS SPECIES REACHES REPRODUCTIVE MATURITY, A VITAL PARAMETER WITHIN POPULATION MODELS. SUCCESS OF THE PROJECT WILL BE DETERMINED BY EVALUATING THE NUMBER OF BLACK VULTURE NESTS MONITORED AND THE AMOUNT OF LOCATION DATA COLLECTED FROM THE GPS BACKPACKS.  THE METHODS USED TO DETERMINE THE SUCCESS OF THE PROJECT WILL REVOLVE AROUND THE COLLECTED DATA. BASED ON THE QUALITY AND QUANTITY OF DATA COLLECTED PERSONNEL WILL EVALUATE THE ABILITY TO IDENTIFY AND UNDERSTAND MOVEMENTS AND SURVIVAL OF THE SPECIES USING APPROPRIATE STATISTICAL TOOLS FOR EACH QUESTION. CONFIDENCE INTERVALS FROM THOSE TESTS WILL BE USED TO GAUGE THE RELIABILITY OF THOSE ESTIMATES FOR MANAGEMENT APPLICATION AND DECISIONS. IN ADDITION, PERSONNEL WILL IDENTIFY ANY WEAKNESSES RELATED TO THE DATA COLLECTION METHODS, DATA QUALITY, AND ANALYSIS POWER TO ATTEMPT TO DETERMINE ANY PLACES WHERE OBJECTIVES WERE NOT MET, AND ANY FUTURE RESEARCH NEEDS TO OVERCOME THOSE WEAKNESSES.  THE RESEARCH COMMUNITY, AND COMMUNITY AT LARGE, WILL BENEFIT FROM THE PROJECT INVOLVING BLACK VULTURE NEST MONITORING AND GPS TELEMETRY OF FLEDGLING VULTURES TO FILL SOME OF THE AREAS IN WHICH RESEARCHERS AND MANAGERS LACK PROPER PARAMETER ESTIMATES ON THE POPULATION OR THEIR BEHAVIORS.  THERE ARE NO ANTICIPATED SUB-AWARDEES.
